posts.cooked: Does anyone know how a CIM would perform as a dynamo? How fast would it need to spin in order to power another CIM ? I assume a similar speed would result on the other side. Non- FRC application, obviously.

posts.name: GaryVoshol
posts.cooked:
four:

How fast would it need to spin in order to power another CIM ?

Sounds kind of like perpetual motion. You’re never going to be able to get as much out as it takes to make it spin.

posts.name: Marshall Hamon
posts.cooked:
The speed would be fairly similar, but there’d be ~20% less torque in the motor you’re driving, more so depending on how long the wires are. You would need the cim to be spinning really fast to reach a minimum voltage to overcome static friction, I’d guess at least 150RPM (if not higher.) If you’re using a dynamo, you’ll definitely want a reduction), unless you are using some form of mechanical power that reaches those rpms manually

EDIT: I vastly overestimated how efficient CIM motors are. As Richard Wallace said, the efficiency would be much lower.

Should probably clarify that I am not talking about perpetual motion. Sorry for the confusion.

We are looking at using electrical energy transmission instead of mechanical in a hand cranked system.

So: in__________________________________________out

We are looking at spinning a fairy heavy disk so output gearing will also be involved.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
four:

I assume a similar speed would result on the other side.

The second law of thermodynamics rears its ugly head.

image 1015×609 49.8 KB

image 1015×609 49.8 KB

image 1015×609 49.8 KB

At best, a CIM motor will convert between electrical/mechanical energy at a 65% efficiency rate. Two conversions means only 42% of the input power you apply shows up at the output shaft. But note doing this also requires some electrical regulation (current/voltage buck-boost tradeoffs) to keep the output motor at its peak operation efficiency point too… IRL you’ll be lower efficiency.

So, fun experiment for sure, but I’ll be the results are a bit lackluster.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
Hi, St. Louis.  I’m Richard.  Was part of the FRC community there before I moved to Michigan fifteen years ago.

I can probably help with this.  Motors are my thing.  PM me with a few details and I’ll show you how the math works.

Edit:  Chris is right, efficiency will not be good.  But whether that’s important depends on the details of what you’re trying to do.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked: Mark Koors created a wind turbine to generate power using a CIM motor. It was pretty cool.

Okay, so basically we are trying to transfer power from a human driven crank to spin a large disk. (To be honest, this is a bit more of a side tangent that we are exploring while designing a purely mechanical solution, but we are still considering it). The disk is probably ~19 kg. CIM peak efficiency looks to be ~4800 RPM so the input needs to be geared up to that speed. Then the output from the output CIM needs to be geared down, of course.

The whole though behind this idea was that it would be easier for small children to turn the crank, but that does not make much sense from an energy perspective with the low efficiency of all these gearboxes and motors.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
So the general idea is something that would be schematically described like this: image 1281×556 22.6 KB

image 1281×556 22.6 KB

image 1281×556 22.6 KB

Two CIMS, electrically connected so that electrical energy generated by the one on the left (by hand cranking through a speed increaser) is consumed by the one on the right, which delivers mechanical power (through a speed reducer) to accelerate and then maintain rotation of the 70 inch diameter, 19 kg acrylic disk.  Do I have this right so far?

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Given you don’t seem to have much space constraints, going with a belt reduction may be more efficient than gears for your final. Eek out a few more %. If you try to do it in a single stage you might need idlers though as I imagine your wrap angle on the output CIM pulley would be pretty small. You can mitigate that by a few teeth by increasing the center to center distance.

Also try to get very free running bearings - the typical shielded and sealed bearings can add a little bit of drag and may not offer any benefits in your demo application.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
four:

The 20:1 reduction was for human power though so I imagine it will need to be more than that for a motor.

I think you’re right.  For example, if you got the voltage at the Motor CIM terminals up to 10V by cranking, disk speed with 20:1 reduction would be over 180 RPM (3 rev/sec) so linear speed at the disk edge would be 55 ft/sec (37 MPH).  Maybe faster than you had in mind.

I think you’ll want to include a switch, breaker, and ammeter in series with the wiring, and probably a light bulb or LED circuit in parallel with the generator.  The series components should be rated for 50A or so.

Also, the speed increase ratio from crank to generator should be about double the value of the reduction ratio from motor to disk.

How long will the wires be? If your application needs some distance between the crank and the disk, and especially if a mechanism to span that distance would be awkward, then this electrical coupling idea could be a good alternative. If you go this way, please use appropriate wire – I think 10 AWG would be a good choice.

Okay, so the project has been canceled, but I would still like to work out the theoretical for learning purposes.

Would there be use in having diodes in series with the motors in order to prevent the disk from backdriving the system?

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
A bridge rectifier would allow your disc to continue spinning when you stop cranking.

Two stepper motors would give you a 1:1 synchronus electromechanical system, but you might not like the bump-bump-bump aspect.

Coupling two NEOs would give you more efficient power transmission but much more $$

posts.cooked: One or two years at an intro frc course, we put 2 Cims on a tough box, powered 1 and used the other to power a third electrically. Nice demo, terrible efficiency.
